title: Ecclesiastes Chapter 3 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ecclesiastes chapter 3 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ecclesiastes Chapter 3 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ecclesiastes Chapter 3.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 3:1, what is there to every thing under heaven?
options: A season and a time to every purpose
A place and a reason
A blessing and a curse
A beginning and an end
questions.correctAnswer: A season and a time to every purpose
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 3:1 states, 'To every thing there is a season, and a time to every purpose under the heaven,' indicating the correct answer.

questions.question: Which pair is mentioned in Ecclesiastes 3:2 as having a time?
options: A time to be born, and a time to die
A time to build, and a time to destroy
A time to laugh, and a time to be silent
A time to fight, and a time to rest
questions.correctAnswer: A time to be born, and a time to die
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 3:2 says, 'A time to be born, and a time to die;' which is the correct pair mentioned.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 3:4, what is paired with a time to weep?
options: A time to laugh
A time to shout
A time to rest
A time to sing
questions.correctAnswer: A time to laugh
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 3:4 states, 'A time to weep, and a time to laugh;' so the correct answer is 'A time to laugh.'

questions.question: What does Ecclesiastes 3:6 say there is a time to do?
options: A time to get, and a time to lose
A time to plant, and a time to harvest
A time to love, and a time to hate
A time to speak, and a time to listen
questions.correctAnswer: A time to get, and a time to lose
questions.explanation: Verse 6 lists 'A time to get, and a time to lose;' as one of the pairs.

questions.question: In Ecclesiastes 3:8, what is said to have a time?
options: A time of war, and a time of peace
A time to build, and a time to break
A time to teach, and a time to learn
A time to sing, and a time to pray
questions.correctAnswer: A time of war, and a time of peace
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 3:8 mentions 'a time of war, and a time of peace' as part of its pairs.

questions.question: What does Ecclesiastes 3:11 say God has made beautiful in his time?
options: Every thing
The earth
The heavens
The hearts of men
questions.correctAnswer: Every thing
questions.explanation: Verse 11 states, 'He hath made every thing beautiful in his time,' confirming the correct answer.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 3:12, what is good for a man to do?
options: Rejoice and do good in his life
Fast and pray daily
Build houses and plant vineyards
Seek wisdom and knowledge
questions.correctAnswer: Rejoice and do good in his life
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 3:12 says, 'there is no good in them, but for a man to rejoice, and to do good in his life.'

questions.question: What gift does Ecclesiastes 3:13 say every man should enjoy?
options: To eat and drink, and enjoy the good of all his labour
To have riches and honor
To live long and prosper
To have peace and safety
questions.correctAnswer: To eat and drink, and enjoy the good of all his labour
questions.explanation: Verse 13 states: 'And also that every man should eat and drink, and enjoy the good of all his labour, it is the gift of God.'

questions.question: True or False: Ecclesiastes 3:15 says that nothing can be added to or taken from what God does.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 3:14 explains that 'nothing can be put to it, nor any thing taken from it,' referring to God's works.

questions.question: Where did the author see wickedness and iniquity according to Ecclesiastes 3:16?
options: In the place of judgment and the place of righteousness
In the temple and the marketplace
In the hearts of men
In the wilderness
questions.correctAnswer: In the place of judgment and the place of righteousness
questions.explanation: Verse 16 states, 'under the sun the place of judgment, that wickedness was there; and the place of righteousness, that iniquity was there.'

questions.question: True or False: Ecclesiastes 3:17 says God shall judge both the righteous and the wicked.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 3:17 confirms, 'God shall judge the righteous and the wicked.'

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 3:19, what do men and beasts share?
options: One breath
One soul
One spirit
One destiny
questions.correctAnswer: One breath
questions.explanation: Verse 19 states, 'yea, they have all one breath,' referring to both men and beasts.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Ecclesiastes 3:20: 'All go unto one place; all are of the dust, and all turn to ______ again.'
options: dust
earth
ashes
nothing
questions.correctAnswer: dust
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 3:20 says, 'all turn to dust again,' so the correct word to fill in is 'dust.'

questions.question: Who knows the spirit of man going upward and the spirit of beasts going downward, according to Ecclesiastes 3:21?
options: No one knows
The angels know
God knows
The wise men know
questions.correctAnswer: No one knows
questions.explanation: Verse 21 asks, 'Who knoweth the spirit of man that goeth upward, and the spirit of the beast that goeth downward to the earth?', implying no one knows.

questions.question: True or False: Ecclesiastes 3:22 says that it is better for a man to rejoice in his own works.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 22 states, 'there is nothing better, than that a man should rejoice in his own works.'

medium.title: Ecclesiastes Chapter 3 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ecclesiastes Chapter 3 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Ecclesiastes 3:1-8 teach us about understanding the seasons of life in relation to patience and trust in God?
options: There is a time and season for every activity under heaven, teaching us to trust God's timing.
We should act immediately without waiting for the right time.
Seasons of life are unpredictable and cannot be understood.
God does not control the timing of events in our lives.
questions.correctAnswer: There is a time and season for every activity under heaven, teaching us to trust God's timing.
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 3:1-8 describes a time for every purpose and activity under heaven, illustrating that God ordains seasons in life. This teaches patience and trust in His timing (Ecclesiastes 3:1-8).

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with grief and asks how to balance sorrow and joy. Based on Ecclesiastes 3:4, what biblical truth would you share?
options: There is a time to weep and a time to laugh; both emotions have their place in God's plan.
Sorrow should always be avoided because it is a sign of weak faith.
Joy should be expressed only in public settings, not in private.
We should ignore grief and focus only on happiness.
questions.correctAnswer: There is a time to weep and a time to laugh; both emotions have their place in God's plan.
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 3:4 shows that God has ordained a time to mourn and a time to dance, teaching us to accept both sorrow and joy as part of life under His sovereignty.

questions.question: How does Ecclesiastes 3:12-13 encourage contentment and gratitude in our daily work?
options: We should rejoice and enjoy the fruits of our labor as gifts from God.
Work is meaningless and should be avoided.
Only spiritual activities have value, not our daily work.
Our labor is solely for personal gain without spiritual significance.
questions.correctAnswer: We should rejoice and enjoy the fruits of our labor as gifts from God.
questions.explanation: Verses 12-13 teach that there is good in rejoicing and doing good in life, and enjoying the results of our labor is a gift from God, encouraging gratitude and contentment.

questions.question: A believer faces uncertainty about the future and wonders how to respond. According to Ecclesiastes 3:15, what principle should guide their trust?
options: What has been will be again; therefore, trust God's eternal plan.
The future is entirely unpredictable, so worry is justified.
We can change the past by our actions today.
God does not require us to consider past events.
questions.correctAnswer: What has been will be again; therefore, trust God's eternal plan.
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 3:15 says that what has been is now and what is to be has already been, teaching that God's plan is eternal and trustworthy.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 3:17, how does understanding God's judgment encourage perseverance through trials?
options: God will judge the righteous and wicked in their appointed time, giving hope for justice.
Judgment is uncertain and unpredictable.
We must judge others to avoid God's judgment.
There is no judgment to fear, so perseverance is unnecessary.
questions.correctAnswer: God will judge the righteous and wicked in their appointed time, giving hope for justice.
questions.explanation: Verse 17 teaches that God will judge both righteous and wicked, reminding believers to persevere with hope in divine justice.

questions.question: How does Ecclesiastes 3:11 describe God's wisdom in the timing and beauty of His works, encouraging humility and trust?
options: God makes everything beautiful in its time, but humans cannot fully understand His work.
Humans can comprehend all of God's plans completely.
God's work is chaotic and without order.
We should rely on our own understanding instead of God's timing.
questions.correctAnswer: God makes everything beautiful in its time, but humans cannot fully understand His work.
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 3:11 states that God has made everything beautiful in its time and that no one can fully comprehend His work from beginning to end, promoting humility and trust.

questions.question: A believer struggles with finding meaning in work. Based on Ecclesiastes 3:9-10, what biblical perspective would you offer?
options: Work is a gift from God to be exercised in life, even if its profit seems uncertain.
Work is pointless and should be avoided.
Only spiritual work matters, not daily labor.
Profit from work is guaranteed and the sole purpose of labor.
questions.correctAnswer: Work is a gift from God to be exercised in life, even if its profit seems uncertain.
questions.explanation: Verses 9-10 explain that God has given people the task of laboring in life, even if its profit is not always clear, encouraging faithful work ethic.

questions.question: How does Ecclesiastes 3:14 teach about God's sovereignty and our reverence for Him?
options: Whatever God does is eternal and should cause us to fear Him.
God's actions are temporary and irrelevant.
We can add or remove from God's work without consequence.
Fear of God is unnecessary because He is distant.
questions.correctAnswer: Whatever God does is eternal and should cause us to fear Him.
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 3:14 declares that God's works are eternal and unchangeable, and this should lead us to fear and reverence Him.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 3:19-20, what biblical truth helps us maintain humility concerning life and death?
options: Man and beasts share the same fate—death—so none has preeminence, reminding us of humility.
Humans are immortal and superior to all creatures.
Death is avoidable through human wisdom.
Beasts are superior to humans in God's eyes.
questions.correctAnswer: Man and beasts share the same fate—death—so none has preeminence, reminding us of humility.
questions.explanation: Verses 19-20 teach that both humans and beasts die and return to dust, emphasizing humility about our mortality.

questions.question: A believer is anxious about the unknown after death. How does Ecclesiastes 3:21 inform our understanding of the spirit and encourage trust in God's plan?
options: No one knows if the spirit of man goes upward or the spirit of beasts goes downward, so we trust God’s wisdom.
The spirit of man clearly goes downward like beasts.
The spirit of beasts is superior to humans.
We can fully understand what happens to the spirit after death.
questions.correctAnswer: No one knows if the spirit of man goes upward or the spirit of beasts goes downward, so we trust God’s wisdom.
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 3:21 acknowledges the mystery of the spirit's destiny and encourages trusting God’s sovereign plan.

questions.question: How does Ecclesiastes 3:7 teach about balancing speech and silence in our relationships and spiritual discipline?
options: There is a time to keep silence and a time to speak, guiding wise communication.
We should always speak our mind regardless of timing.
Silence is always better than speaking.
Speaking is more important than listening.
questions.correctAnswer: There is a time to keep silence and a time to speak, guiding wise communication.
questions.explanation: Verse 7 teaches that God ordains times for both silence and speech, encouraging discernment in communication.

questions.question: True or False: Ecclesiastes 3:16 shows that injustice exists even where righteousness should be, reminding us to trust God's ultimate judgment.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 16 notes that under the sun, wickedness can be found in places of judgment and iniquity where righteousness is expected, reminding us to rely on God's final justice.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ecclesiastes 3:13, enjoying the fruits of our labor is considered a blessing and gift from God.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 13 clearly states that eating, drinking, and enjoying one's labor is a gift from God, encouraging gratitude.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Ecclesiastes 3 teaches that there is a time to love and a time to ____.
options: hate
fight
pray
forgive
questions.correctAnswer: hate
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 3:8 states there is a time to love and a time to hate, illustrating the seasons and contrasts in life ordained by God.

questions.question: How does Ecclesiastes 3:22 encourage a believer to find joy and purpose in daily life despite uncertainty about the future?
options: There is nothing better than to rejoice in one's own works, as this is the portion given by God.
Worrying about the future is the best way to prepare.
Only spiritual achievements matter, not daily work.
The future should be ignored, focusing only on the past.
questions.correctAnswer: There is nothing better than to rejoice in one's own works, as this is the portion given by God.
questions.explanation: Verse 22 encourages rejoicing in the work we do as our portion because the future is unknown, fostering contentment and gratitude.

hard.title: Ecclesiastes Chapter 3 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ecclesiastes Chapter 3.

questions.question: Ecclesiastes 3 opens with a famous verse about timing. What literary device is primarily used in Ecclesiastes 3:1 to express the concept of divine timing?
options: Parallelism
Metaphor
Chiasm
Allegory
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 3:1 uses parallelism by pairing 'a season' with 'a time' and 'every purpose' with 'under the heaven,' reflecting a poetic structure common in Hebrew wisdom literature.

questions.question: Which of the following pairs is NOT listed as a 'time' or season in Ecclesiastes 3:2-8?
options: A time to build up, and a time to break down
A time to love, and a time to hate
A time to sow, and a time to reap
A time to laugh, and a time to weep
questions.correctAnswer: A time to sow, and a time to reap
questions.explanation: While 'a time to plant, and a time to pluck up that which is planted' appears in Ecclesiastes 3:2, the phrase 'a time to sow, and a time to reap' is not used explicitly in this chapter.

questions.question: In Ecclesiastes 3:11, what is the significant theological assertion about God's work and human understanding?
options: God's work is inscrutable and cannot be fully comprehended by man
God's work is primarily about judgment
God's work is limited to the natural world
God's work is fully revealed through prophets
questions.correctAnswer: God's work is inscrutable and cannot be fully comprehended by man
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 3:11 states that God has set eternity in man's heart but no one can fathom the work God has done from beginning to end, emphasizing divine mystery.

questions.question: Ecclesiastes 3:14 declares that whatever God does will last forever. This idea most closely parallels which New Testament teaching?
options: Jesus teaching about eternal life in John 3:16
Paul's teaching on the unchangeableness of God in Hebrews 13:8
The permanence of God's word in Matthew 24:35
The fruit of the Spirit in Galatians 5:22-23
questions.correctAnswer: The permanence of God's word in Matthew 24:35
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 3:14's emphasis on the eternal nature of God's actions parallels Jesus' statement in Matthew 24:35 that heaven and earth will pass away but His words will not.

questions.question: What is the main theme of the series of opposites listed in Ecclesiastes 3:1-8?
options: The cyclical nature of life and divine timing
The inevitability of death
The futility of labor
The contrast between good and evil
questions.correctAnswer: The cyclical nature of life and divine timing
questions.explanation: The pairs of opposites highlight that there is an appointed time for every activity under heaven, emphasizing cycles and divine order (Ecclesiastes 3:1-8).

questions.question: Ecclesiastes 3:9 asks, 'What profit hath he that worketh in that wherein he laboureth?' This rhetorical question reflects which broader biblical theme?
options: The vanity of human toil without God
The blessing of hard work
The reward of righteousness
The futility of sin
questions.correctAnswer: The vanity of human toil without God
questions.explanation: The question points to the philosophical inquiry into human labor’s ultimate value, a key theme in Ecclesiastes regarding the vanity or meaninglessness of life apart from divine purpose.

questions.question: Ecclesiastes 3:12-13 suggest a particular attitude toward life’s pleasures. Which theological perspective does this represent?
options: Enjoying God's gifts as a divine blessing
Ascetic denial of worldly pleasures
Predestination and fatalism
Judgment and repentance
questions.correctAnswer: Enjoying God's gifts as a divine blessing
questions.explanation: Verses 12-13 encourage rejoicing and enjoying the fruits of one’s labor as gifts from God, reflecting a positive view of life’s blessings within the fear of God.

questions.question: True or False: Ecclesiastes 3:15 states that what has been will never happen again and what is to be will be entirely new.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 3:15 actually says, 'That which hath been is now; and that which is to be hath already been,' indicating a cyclical or repetitive view of time, not something entirely new.

questions.question: Ecclesiastes 3:16-17 discusses judgment and the presence of wickedness and righteousness. What literary device is used to emphasize the paradox of injustice observed 'under the sun'?
options: Irony
Simile
Hyperbole
Foreshadowing
questions.correctAnswer: Irony
questions.explanation: The passage highlights the irony that places of judgment contain both wickedness and iniquity, underscoring the imperfect justice experienced in the earthly realm.

questions.question: Ecclesiastes 3:18-21 compares humans to beasts. What does this comparison reveal about the author's view of human existence?
options: Humans share the same mortality and breath as animals, emphasizing life's vanity
Humans are superior to animals in every way
Humans have an immortal soul unlike animals
Humans are destined to dominate animals
questions.correctAnswer: Humans share the same mortality and breath as animals, emphasizing life's vanity
questions.explanation: The text stresses that both humans and beasts share death and breath, highlighting the transient and vanity nature of life (Ecclesiastes 3:18-19).

questions.question: What question raised in Ecclesiastes 3:21 reflects the ancient Near Eastern view of life and the afterlife?
options: Who knows the spirit of man that goes upward, and the spirit of the beast that goes downward?
Why are humans made in God's image?
What is the meaning of righteousness?
How does one attain wisdom?
questions.correctAnswer: Who knows the spirit of man that goes upward, and the spirit of the beast that goes downward?
questions.explanation: This verse questions the fate of the human spirit compared to animals, reflecting uncertainty about the afterlife common in ancient Near Eastern thought.

questions.question: In Ecclesiastes 3:22, the author concludes with a practical resolution. What is it?
options: Man should rejoice in his works for that is his portion
Man should seek eternal life through wisdom
Man should fear God and repent
Man should avoid labor and seek rest
questions.correctAnswer: Man should rejoice in his works for that is his portion
questions.explanation: The author advises rejoicing in one's own labor as the best course since the future is unknown (Ecclesiastes 3:22).

questions.question: Ecclesiastes 3:7 contrasts a 'time to keep silence' and a 'time to speak.' In biblical wisdom literature, what does this reflect about the use of speech?
options: Speech must be used judiciously according to the right season
Speech is always to be avoided
Silence is a sign of weakness
Speaking often is a sign of wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: Speech must be used judiciously according to the right season
questions.explanation: This verse highlights the wisdom principle that timing governs appropriate speech and silence (Ecclesiastes 3:7).

questions.question: How does the theme of 'a time to love and a time to hate' in Ecclesiastes 3:8 correspond to Old Testament covenant theology?
options: It reflects that emotions and actions are regulated under God's sovereign timing
It advocates indiscriminate hatred
It contradicts the command to love one's neighbor
It promotes war as a constant state
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects that emotions and actions are regulated under God's sovereign timing
questions.explanation: The verse recognizes that God ordains times for various emotions and actions, consistent with covenantal obedience and divine sovereignty in the Old Testament.

questions.question: Ecclesiastes 3:6 mentions 'a time to get, and a time to lose; a time to keep, and a time to cast away.' What cultural practice from the ancient Near East might this reflect?
options: Agricultural cycles and property management
Religious festivals
Military conquest
Priestly rituals
questions.correctAnswer: Agricultural cycles and property management
questions.explanation: These contrasts resonate with agrarian societies’ cycles of acquiring and losing crops or possessions, reflecting the economic realities of the ancient Near East.

theological.title: Ecclesiastes Chapter 3 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ecclesiastes Chapter 3 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What theological truth is expressed by the statement 'To every thing there is a season, and a time to every purpose under the heaven'?
options: God sovereignly ordains all events in human history
Everything happens by chance and fate
Human decisions control the times and seasons
Seasons are irrelevant to God's plan
questions.correctAnswer: God sovereignly ordains all events in human history
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 3:1 teaches that God has appointed a specific time and purpose for everything, affirming His sovereignty over history. This is consistent with Daniel 2:21, Psalm 31:15, Isaiah 46:10, and Acts 17:26 where God controls times and seasons.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 3, what contrast is drawn to demonstrate the balance in God's providential timing?
options: A time to be born, and a time to die
A time to build up, and a time to break down
A time to love, and a time to hate
All of the above
questions.correctAnswer: All of the above
questions.explanation: Verses 2-8 list contrasting pairs showing God's ordained times for various life events, highlighting divine balance and order. This theme is echoed in Genesis 8:22, James 3:17, and Romans 8:28 where God's timing and purposes are perfect.

questions.question: What question does the preacher ask about human labor in Ecclesiastes 3:9?
options: What profit hath he that worketh in that wherein he laboureth?
Is labor the cause of sin?
Does labor guarantee eternal life?
Can labor be avoided in this life?
questions.correctAnswer: What profit hath he that worketh in that wherein he laboureth?
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 3:9 questions the ultimate benefit of human toil, reflecting on the vanity of life apart from God's blessing. This resonates with 1 Corinthians 15:58, Colossians 3:23-24, and Proverbs 16:3, which affirm working as unto the Lord for eternal reward.

questions.question: What does Ecclesiastes 3:11 reveal about God's wisdom and human understanding?
options: God has made everything beautiful in its time, but humans cannot fully comprehend His work
Humans can fully understand God's plan by studying nature
God's work is chaotic and without purpose
Humans have control over God's timing
questions.correctAnswer: God has made everything beautiful in its time, but humans cannot fully comprehend His work
questions.explanation: The verse teaches that God's timing is perfect and beyond human full understanding, emphasizing divine mystery. This is consistent with Isaiah 55:8-9, Romans 11:33, Job 11:7-9, and 1 Corinthians 2:9-11 which describe the inscrutable wisdom of God.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 3:12-13, what is the appropriate human response to God's providential timing?
options: To rejoice and enjoy the good of all labor as a gift from God
To despair because life is meaningless
To seek wealth as the ultimate goal
To avoid labor to escape vanity
questions.correctAnswer: To rejoice and enjoy the good of all labor as a gift from God
questions.explanation: These verses teach that joy in one's work and life is a God-given blessing, highlighting gratitude and contentment. This aligns with Psalm 128:2, Ecclesiastes 5:18, 1 Timothy 6:17, and Philippians 4:11-13 on contentment and divine provision.

questions.question: What eternal principle concerning God's works is declared in Ecclesiastes 3:14?
options: God's works are eternal, unchangeable, and inspire reverence
God's works are temporary and subject to human alteration
God's works depend on human effort to succeed
God's works can be ignored without consequence
questions.correctAnswer: God's works are eternal, unchangeable, and inspire reverence
questions.explanation: This verse affirms God's immutable nature and the permanence of His actions, calling humans to fear Him. This doctrine is supported by Malachi 3:6, Hebrews 13:8, James 1:17, and Psalm 90:2 on God's eternal constancy.

questions.question: What does Ecclesiastes 3:15 teach about the cyclical nature of time and God's sovereignty?
options: That which has been is now; God requires what is past
Time is linear and solely controlled by humans
The past is irrelevant to God's judgment
The future is unpredictable and outside God's control
questions.correctAnswer: That which has been is now; God requires what is past
questions.explanation: The verse emphasizes God's control over all time and His accountability for past actions, consistent with Hebrews 13:8, Isaiah 46:10, Romans 14:12, and 2 Corinthians 5:10 regarding God's sovereignty and final judgment.

questions.question: What observation does Ecclesiastes 3:16 make about judgment and evil under the sun?
options: Wickedness is found in the place of judgment and iniquity in the place of righteousness
Judgment always triumphs over evil
Righteousness completely eradicates wickedness
There is no evil in human institutions
questions.correctAnswer: Wickedness is found in the place of judgment and iniquity in the place of righteousness
questions.explanation: This verse exposes the imperfect justice of earthly systems, highlighting human sinfulness. Similar realities are described in Isaiah 1:23, Psalm 94:20, Proverbs 17:15, and Romans 3:10-18 about corruption and injustice among men.

questions.question: How does Ecclesiastes 3:17 express confidence in divine judgment?
options: God shall judge the righteous and the wicked; there is a time for every purpose
Humans alone decide what is just
Judgment is arbitrary and unpredictable
There will be no final judgment
questions.correctAnswer: God shall judge the righteous and the wicked; there is a time for every purpose
questions.explanation: The verse affirms God's role as final judge over all human actions, consistent with Acts 17:31, 2 Timothy 4:1, Revelation 20:12, and Romans 14:10 on divine judgment and accountability.

questions.question: What anthropological truth is stated in Ecclesiastes 3:18-19 regarding humans and beasts?
options: Both humans and beasts share the same fate of death and breath; all is vanity
Humans are immortal unlike beasts
Beasts have superior wisdom to humans
Humans have no relation to the rest of creation
questions.correctAnswer: Both humans and beasts share the same fate of death and breath; all is vanity
questions.explanation: These verses emphasize human mortality and shared physical end with animals, underscoring the vanity of life apart from God. This truth is supported by Genesis 2:7, Psalm 49:12, Ecclesiastes 12:7, and Hebrews 9:27 on death and human nature.

questions.question: What existential reality does Ecclesiastes 3:20 declare about the destiny of all living beings?
options: All go unto one place; all are of the dust, and all turn to dust again
Some escape death by their works
Only humans return to dust, beasts do not
The spirit immediately goes to heaven upon death
questions.correctAnswer: All go unto one place; all are of the dust, and all turn to dust again
questions.explanation: The verse teaches the universal mortality of all life, highlighting human dependence on God for eternal hope. This is consistent with Genesis 3:19, Job 34:15, Psalm 104:29, and Ecclesiastes 12:7 on death and the return to dust.

questions.question: What uncertainty about the afterlife is expressed in Ecclesiastes 3:21?
options: Who knows the spirit of man that goes upward, and the spirit of the beast that goes downward?
The afterlife is clearly understood by all
The spirit of beasts ascends to heaven like humans
Humans do not have a spirit
questions.correctAnswer: Who knows the spirit of man that goes upward, and the spirit of the beast that goes downward?
questions.explanation: This verse expresses the mystery surrounding the destiny of human and animal spirits, emphasizing human limitations in understanding. Similar mystery is found in Job 14:14, Ecclesiastes 8:8, 1 Corinthians 2:11, and Hebrews 9:27 about life after death.

questions.question: What conclusion does the author draw in Ecclesiastes 3:22 about the best course for humans in life?
options: To rejoice in their works, as that is their portion
To seek knowledge of the future at all costs
To avoid labor because it is vain
To trust in human wisdom over God
questions.correctAnswer: To rejoice in their works, as that is their portion
questions.explanation: The verse encourages contentment and joy in one's labor as God's gift, affirming trust in God's providence. This aligns with Nehemiah 8:10, Philippians 4:4, 1 Thessalonians 5:16-18, and Psalm 128:2 on rejoicing and gratitude.

questions.question: In Ecclesiastes 3:7, what duality is presented regarding human communication and action?
options: A time to keep silence, and a time to speak
A time to teach, and a time to learn
A time to write, and a time to read
A time to pray, and a time to fast
questions.correctAnswer: A time to keep silence, and a time to speak
questions.explanation: The verse highlights the divine timing for speech and silence, emphasizing wisdom in communication. This theme is supported by Proverbs 17:27, Ecclesiastes 10:12, James 1:19, and Matthew 12:36 on the importance of controlling speech.

questions.question: What contrast does Ecclesiastes 3:8 make that reflects the reality of conflict and peace in human history?
options: A time of war, and a time of peace
A time for justice, and a time for mercy
A time for harvest, and a time for famine
A time for prayer, and a time for silence
questions.correctAnswer: A time of war, and a time of peace
questions.explanation: This verse acknowledges the ordained seasons of conflict and tranquility, reflecting God's sovereign control over human affairs. Similar concepts appear in Psalm 46:9, Isaiah 2:4, Romans 12:18, and Revelation 20:1-3 on God's ultimate peace and judgment.
